content.raw: I'm not so sure about having the link inspector here. As I understand it, `ConfigWidget` is supposed to be a general purpose class not dependent to the model editor. And even in the editor itself, it is used by other dialogs such as the `JointInspector`.
content.html: I'm not so sure about having the link inspector here. As I understand it, ConfigWidget is supposed to be a general purpose class not dependent to the model editor. And even in the editor itself, it is used by other dialogs such as the JointInspector.

content.raw:
Yeah, so this gave me some heartburn.    The challenge is that the
ConfigWidget class (and one of its children, the DensityWidget) don't have
access to the other sibling ConfigWidget instances, one of which contains
the collisions which the density widget needs to compute the volume of the
link.

Maybe there's a more direct way to get at that information.   I sure
couldn't find it.
content.html:
Yeah, so this gave me some heartburn. The challenge is that the ConfigWidget class (and one of its children, the DensityWidget) don't have access to the other sibling ConfigWidget instances, one of which contains the collisions which the density widget needs to compute the volume of the link.

Maybe there's a more direct way to get at that information. I sure couldn't find it.

Maybe we can handle the coordination between the different config widgets from the link inspector? The link inspector can listen to density changes in its LinkConfig and update mass and inertia based on its CollisionConfig.

Something like this:

LinkInspector::LinkInspector(QWidget *_parent) : QDialog(_parent)
{
  ...
  connect(this->dataPtr->linkConfig,
        SIGNAL(DensityValueChanged(const QString &, const double &)), this,
        SLOT(OnDensityChanged(const QString &, const double &)));
}

LinkInspector::OnDensityChanged(const QString &/*_name*/, const double &_value)
{
  // Get geometry from collision configs
  this->dataPtr->collisionConfig->GetConfigData()
  ...
  // Update mass and inertia
  this->dataPtr->linkConfig->SetDoubleWidgetValue("inertial::mass", mass);
  ...
}

content.raw: That's an elegant approach.  I think it (the link inspector) would also have to listen to mass and collision changes as well.   The density needs to be set when either the mass or volume change.   I'm thinking specifically about the ConfigWidget::Parse(protobuf msg) case when the widgets are created and later updated via protobuf messages.
content.html: That's an elegant approach. I think it (the link inspector) would also have to listen to mass and collision changes as well. The density needs to be set when either the mass or volume change. I'm thinking specifically about the ConfigWidget::Parse(protobuf msg) case when the widgets are created and later updated via protobuf messages.

content.raw: Yeah, keeping everything in sync would probably require tracking all involved widgets. I'm guessing we would need to update the density after parse is called the first time, and every single time one of the other fields is updated.
content.html: Yeah, keeping everything in sync would probably require tracking all involved widgets. I'm guessing we would need to update the density after parse is called the first time, and every single time one of the other fields is updated.

content.raw:
It's probably more consistent to compute volume based on collisions instead of visuals. 

For mass/inertia, [collisions are used](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/1836/update-inertial-values-when-links-are/diff#Lgazebo/gui/model/ModelData.ccT199).
content.html:
It's probably more consistent to compute volume based on collisions instead of visuals.

For mass/inertia, collisions are used.

content.raw: Or maybe collisions are already being used here as well? The `linkVisual` variable might be misleading me.
content.html: Or maybe collisions are already being used here as well? The linkVisual variable might be misleading me.

content.raw: Related to my previous comment on about the link inspector, maybe we can have a `DensityValueChanged` signal besides these two, or instead of them. I haven't thought this through, but we could keep these for internally updating each other (combo changes updates spin and vice versa), and a the `DensityValueChanged` would be an interface with other classes. Does that make sense?

I haven't thought this through, but we could keep these for internally updating each other (combo changes updates spin and vice versa), and a the DensityValueChanged would be an interface with other classes. Does that make sense?
